By WWDMMax on Thursday, March 25, 2010 - 08:13 am:

I avoided Hop-a-bout for years (until recently, in fact) but when I played it, I fell in love with it. So, this isn't all bad news, right?

By Penguin God on Thursday, March 25, 2010 - 10:04 am:

By WWDMMax on Thursday, March 25, 2010 - 11:10 am:

I hate to bring bad news, but Monster Racer has -NOTHING- to do with Monster Rancher. I did a quick check on Youtube (since it was unveiled sometime during the previous E3) and the only thing they share in common is the word "Monster" from what the trailer showed. The monster design is more in line with Pokemon or Shin Megami Tensei, and the sound effects more akin to the former. There's even a video showing the entire species library and nothing from our beloved monster world. Speaking of worlds, the setting for the game is the real-world Earth and not the fictional regions either.

By Lisa Shock on Saturday, April 17, 2010 - 02:21 pm:

Gamestop gets their dates via the order process, when their buyers write a PO for the item, the publisher gives them a ship date, and updated info if that changes. That's why their dates are better.

By Subster on Saturday, April 17, 2010 - 02:59 pm:

By TracedInAir on Sunday, April 18, 2010 - 12:44 pm:

I'm extremely concerned with how well MR:DS is going to do sales-wise. Looking at the MR:DS facebook page, it only has 287 fans, whereas the Earthbound facebook page (a good comparison since it's also an underrated game with a small cult following) has over 8000. I imagine that the number of people who are going to buy MR:DS is going to be higher than 287, but my point is that the game won't sell well, as Monster Rancher is far from the most popular franchise nowadays. Even little kids aren't attracted to it since the show doesn't play on TV anymore. In other words: the game is screwed because virtually no one will hear or care about it.

I'll still buy it, and maybe I'll even get some of my nerdy friends with DS's to buy a copy, but let's face it: Monster Rancher appeals to a very small demographic, because on the surface it seems too immature and "kiddy" for adults, but in terms of gameplay it's too complex for most kids.

By fiffa46 on Monday, April 19, 2010 - 07:56 am:

It's not even remotely realistic to compare sales with facebook fans. I really don't even know why you would try.

I'm not a facebook fan, so am I not going to buy the game? You better believe I am going to. However, I do not have a facebook account nor do I wish to ever have one.

By TracedInAir on Monday, April 19, 2010 - 02:36 pm:

If you take the proportion of sales of a game to the number of fans on its facebook page, they'll be roughly equal among most games. I never made any silly generalizations like "# of fans on facebook page = # of sales", nor did I say that not being a fan on facebook precluded the possibility of you buying the game

By TracedInAir on Monday, April 19, 2010 - 02:42 pm:

This is an easily testable hypothesis. I predict Monster Rancher DS will sell between 4000 and 5000 copies (this isn't a random number but the result of a simple calculation). If I'm wrong, you win.

To make my point clear: You're wrong TracedInAir.
